thread.title: Calgary Stampeders anxious to finally get a look at Ticats' new digs | Stampeder
thread.title_full: Calgary Stampeders anxious to finally get a look at Ticats' new digs | Stampeder

author: torontosun.com
title: Calgary Stampeders anxious to finally get a look at Ticats' new digs | Stampeder
text:
HAMILTON — The Calgary Stampeders are late to the housewarming party.
In fact, they missed it altogether.
The Stamps will be the last CFL team to visit Tim Hortons Field, the shiny new home of the Hamilton Tiger-Cats, when they show up Friday night (5:30 p.m., TSN/News Talk 770).
Former Tiger-Cats slotback Marquay McDaniel was among those excited to check out the 24,000-seat venue.
“I heard it’s nice, it looks nice on film,” McDaniel said. “I haven’t seen the inside yet.
“Winnipeg is real good, so I’m expecting something similar to that.”
It’s quite a bit smaller than Winnipeg’s Investors Group Field but there’s little doubt it’s a massive improvement on Ivor Wynne Stadium, which was built in 1928 and was long past its expiration date when it was torn down three years ago.
Was there a more grim stadium in the country than ol’ Ivor Wynne?
“No, I don’t think so,” Stamps linebacker Keon Raymond said with a laugh. “I think that was, by far, the worst stadium.
“But looking at the film and the games I watched at Tim Hortons, I think they did a phenomenal job with that stadium. It looks good for the league and the city of Hamilton.
“I’m hoping one day we can get something as nice as that.”
The Stamps certainly will if the CalgaryNEXT proposal comes to fruition.
There were still a couple hundred tickets for Friday night’s game remaining as of Thursday afternoon. Those will probably be snapped up by a walkup crowd but if not, it would be the first Tiger-Cats game that hasn’t been sold out since the stadium opened on Labour Day of last year.
Tiger-Cats fans have obviously paid their dues over the years and Raymond said they deserve the modern digs.
“They’re some of the best fans in the league,” Raymond said. “They’re hard-working, blue-collar fans and they love their football. I’m glad they finally got something in Hamilton to call a nice home.”
McDaniel, who developed into one of the top targets in the CFL after leaving the Tiger-Cats for the Stampeders, remembers his time in The Hammer fondly.
“I had a great time there,” McDaniel said. “That’s where I was introduced to the CFL.
“The crowd was always good. We were about a .500 team but the fans at Ivor Wynne were always good.
“I definitely have a lot of good memories there.”
McDaniel, who sits second in the league with 63 catches and third with 815 yards, said when there’s only one game in town, the fans develop a special bond with the team.
“They would come out and were rowdy and excited,” McDaniel said. “They love the Ticats.
“It’s such a small city and they love football.
“Now they’ve got a nice little stadium out there and the fans pack it every week.”
By the time kickoff rolls around, Friday night will likely be no exception.
scott.fisher@sunmedia.ca
twitter.com/SUNScottFisher
Stampeders
